title: Basic Needs & Student Success
text:
The Center for Healthy Communities (CHC) developed the Basic Needs Student Success Survey (BNS3) and administered it to undergraduate students participating in the Educational Opportunity Program (EOP) or the Extended Opportunity Programs and services (EOPS) at 12 colleges across the CSU, CCC and UC systems from 2022 to 2023.
This report provides a top level descriptive analysis of each question in the survey.

title: Basic Needs & Student Success
text:
The Center for Healthy Communities (CHC) developed the Basic Needs Student Success Survey (BNS3) and administered it to undergraduate students participating in the Educational Opportunity Program (EOP) or the Extended Opportunity Programs and services (EOPS) at 12 colleges across the CSU, CCC and UC systems from 2022 to 2023.
This report provides a top level descriptive analysis of each question in the survey.

title: Basic Needs & Student Success
text:
Purpose
The main purpose of this third cross-sectional study was to evaluate the following:

The impact of receiving CalFresh Food Benefits benefits
Barriers to applying to CalFresh Food
College student food insecurity
The impact of and barriers to using other basic needs services

title: Basic Needs & Student Success
text:
Participants

EOP/EOPS offices assisted in the recruitment by emailing interest form links to their EOP/EOPS students.
Students who met the eligibility criteria of being undergraduate EOP/EOPS students and receiving less than 11 meals per week from other services (used as an eligibility criteria when determining CalFresh Food eligibility) were then emailed a survey.
Participants were given a $25 gift card incentive for completing the survey.
EOP/EOPS students were identified as the target population for this survey based on their low-income and first-generation student status, which indicates a higher probability of using CalFresh Food and being likely eligible for CalFresh Food.

A total of 2,110 EOP/EOPS students in California were surveyed from the following campuses:









Disclaimer on Missing Data: Students had the option to select “Prefer not to answer” for all questions or options such as “I don’t know” for a small subset of questions, and these responses were set as missing values. In addition, 186 (8.8%) students did not finish the survey. These two factors are the cause of missing data (i.e., not 100% of respondents reporting). The n reporting refers to the total number of non-missing responses while the percent reporting reflects the percent of non-missing responses.

title: Basic Needs & Student Success
section: Use of Website and Access to Data
text:
Use of Website and Access to Data
